official-title.#text:
To amend the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize
		  programs under part A of title XI of such Act.

cosponsor.#tail:
)
			 introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Newborn Screening Saves Lives
			 Reauthorization Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the

The table of
			 contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 2. Improved newborn and child screening for heritable
				disorders.

Sec. 3. Evaluating the effectiveness of newborn and child
				screening and followup programs.

Sec. 4. Advisory committee on heritable disorders in newborns
				and children.

Sec. 5. Clearinghouse of Newborn Screening
				Information.

Sec. 7. Interagency Coordinating Committee on Newborn and Child
				Screening.

Sec. 8. National contingency plan for newborn
				screening.

Sec. 10. Newborn screening surveillance, followup, and applied
				research.

header.#text:
Newborn
			 screening surveillance, followup, and applied research

Newborn
				screening surveillance, followup, and applied research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall award grants to, or enter into
				cooperative agreements with, eligible entities to develop longitudinal followup
				and tracking programs for newborn screening.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Director of the Centers
				for Disease Control and Prevention

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall incorporate standardized procedures for data management and program
				effectiveness and costs, such as—

text.#text:
Longitudinal
				followup and tracking programs developed through a grant under

studying the costs
				and effectiveness of newborn screening, evaluation and intervention programs,
				and surveillance systems conducted by State-based programs in order to answer
				issues of importance to State and national policymakers;

studying the
				effectiveness of newborn screening followup and intervention programs by
				assessing the health and development of children at school age and as young
				adults;

ensuring
				coordination of surveillance activities, including—

standardized data
				collection and reporting; and

facilitating
				quality improvement in treatment and disease management based on gaps in
				services or care identified by longitudinal tracking systems; and

utilizing data from longitudinal tracking
				systems to support the development and evaluation of evidence-based guidelines
				for diagnosis, treatment, and disease management.

a State or a
				political subdivision of a State;

a consortium of 2
				or more States or subdivisions described in paragraph (1);

any other entity
